newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Italy's Fazio sees average 97 cpi below three pct.
newsitem.headline: Italy's Fazio sees average 97 cpi below three pct.

text.p: Bank of Italy governor Antonio Fazio said on Monday that he believed average consumer price inflation would fall below three percent in 1997.

"The improvement that we have seen has been very strong," Fazio told reporters while attending a meeting of central bank governors. "We are counting on (average CPI in 1997) falling below three percent," he added.
"But you know very well that there are risks for inflation," Fazio said, adding "these come from public finance and labour costs and monetary policy has to reflect these things."
Italian inflation was 2.6 percent year-on-year last month, unchanged from the November level and in line with forecasts.
Average inflation was 3.9 percent, meeting the government target. Prime Minister Romano Prodi's government wants to get 1997 average inflation down to 2.5 percent. Milan newsroom +392-66102321

Fazio also said it was important to look at monthly variations in inflation and not at the year-on-year data because with the latter "you never know if the positive or negative variation is in the last month or in the month at the start (of the period)."

"The 0.1 percent for January 1996 was linked to a revision of the index. We don't know how true that data is," he said. Asked what he expected the January 1997 figure to be like, he replied "Let's hope it's good."

The January 1997 CPI figure will be the first not to incorporate a fall of 0.04 to 0.05 percent which was a direct result of the revision of the inflation basket introduced in January 1996. Milan newsroom +392-66102321
